title: Crispy Tofu Balls
instructions: [Pressing the tofu is the most important step"
column3: "so I’m going to give y’all (I grew up in Texas"
column4: "so I have the liberty to use “y’all” liberally) three pressing options. The first step before you press is the same: Drain the liquid from the box of tofu. Then press.\nMethod 1: (Easiest) Use a tofu-pressing machine! I spotted one of these in Torrance"
column6: "at a little Japanese grocery store. You place a block of tofu in between two plates and turn a small crank to compress it. Though it will press only one block at a time—the boxes of tofu we use come four to a box—you can set it and forget it (but do it three more times if you plan on using all the tofu).\nMethod 2: (Most common) Use two similar-size plates or relatively flat surfaces. Lay out the blocks of tofu flat in a single layer on one of the plates"
column7: "and then put the second plate on top of the tofu. Press the tofu by placing at least 10 pounds of weight on top of the second plate.\nMethod 3: (Most “professional”) We still prepare the tofu this way at our restaurant"
column9: "without question"
column10: "the most efficient way to prepare larger servings. Lay baking racks/grates inside baking sheets"
column11: "then cover racks with clean (lint-free) towels or"
column12: "as we did successfully for four years"
column13: "with neatly folded aprons laid in a single layer as level and as flat as possible across the racks. Yup"
column14: "towels or aprons"
column15: "plural. Because tofu holds so much moisture"
column16: "the liquid constantly spills over"
column17: "and we’ve found very few people who just live to clean. To absorb the moisture"
column18: "and to create much less of a mess"
column19: "we started using layers of cloth.\nLay out the tofu on the covered racks in a single layer"
column20: "organized as tightly as possible. Make sure the tofu doesn’t hang over the sides of the sheets or it won’t be pressed evenly. Next"
column21: "lay another towel/apron on top of the layer of tofu"
column22: "again"
column23: "flat and level. Then lay another equal-size baking sheet + covered rack + tofu on top of that. Repeat the same steps as needed. The top layer should be a baking sheet on which you place 30 to 40 pounds of “stuff” to press down on all the layers. No matter how many layers you stack"
column24: "the tofu should flatten out only slightly"
column25: "not be completely crushed.\nProcessing the tofu is far simpler than pressing it"
column26: "though like pressing"
column27: "there are three different ways to do it. Start with a bowl or a large (22-quart) plastic container made by and known as a Cambro (if you have one of those lying around)"
column28: "and do one of the following:\nMethod 1: Use a food mill"
column29: "which is what we use. This is by far the easiest way to process tofu and get the most consistent texture (and it’s a great method for mashing anything).\nMethod 2: Use a potato masher. Just mash away"
column30: "but you’ll still need to use the third option to smash out any little lumps that the masher doesn’t"
column32: "well"
column33: "mash.\nMethod 3: Mash everything with your hands. (This is the most common way.)\nProcess the tofu until it is a consistent"
column34: "almost pasty texture. If you go with No. 2 or No. 3"
column35: "make sure to smash out all lumps from the tofu or else the seasoning won’t evenly distribute throughout the mix and"
column36: "later"
column37: "the balls.\nAdd chopped scallions"
column39: "corn"
column40: "and ground white pepper to the (hopefully) evenly processed tofu. Stick your hands in (maybe with gloves) and mix all the ingredients. Taste some of the mix from different areas of the bowl/container to make sure it’s evenly seasoned. It should taste savory"
column41: "with little bits of scallion and corn in every bite.\nNow it’s ball-rolling time! Scoop out a tablespoon of the tofu mixture"
column43: "then level out the spoon with your finger. Assertively shake or scoop out the mix into your hand while mostly keeping it in one piece. Firmly clench the tofu by making a fist"
column44: "packing it very tightly so it doesn’t fall apart.\nContinue by shaping into a ball"
column45: "either with one hand or by lightly tossing the ball back and forth between both hands like you’re playing catch with yourself. Lightly roll the tofu between your hands"
column46: "moving your hands in an alternating clockwise motion"
column48: "only more gently to smooth out any cracks. Tofu is very docile; the more you do it"
column49: "the better you’ll get the feel of it (like most things in life). Place tofu balls on a plate or (ideally) a baking sheet rack.\nOptional: Refrigerate the balls overnight"
column50: "uncovered. This will firm them up.\nAdd flour"
column52: "and mushroom bouillon to a bowl. Mix together. It should not be lumpy; the consistency should be not too thin and consistently thick enough to adhere"
column53: "but not so thick it doesn’t drip off your finger.\nEmpty the green rice flakes into a separate bowl or catering pan"
column54: "then mix in half of the dry cornstarch with flakes. Next"
column55: "drop balls into flour paste. Shake off excess paste (we highly recommend using a kitchen “spider” strainer to do this)"
column56: "then roll balls around in the flakes until they’re fully coated. Gently clench the balls to pack one last bit of flakes onto the balls. If flakes start to drop off the balls"
column57: "mix in more of the remaining cornstarch to dry flakes"
column58: "then try again.\nSet balls on a rack.\nOptional: If you plan on making more and hate waste like we do"
column60: "then sift through all the flakes. Throw out any moist clumps of flakes. Store dry flakes in a closed container"
column61: "then refrigerate until your next tofu ball–rolling party!\nOptional: Refrigerate the fully flaked balls uncovered (and preferably elevated on a rack) overnight. This will give the flakes more time to adhere and dry out"
column62: "which is important in giving the balls more puff"
column64: "and an overall prettier look after frying.\nAdd at least 2 inches of oil to a pot"
column66: "then fry the balls for about 3 to 4 minutes"
column67: "or until the flakes puff up bright green and any exposed tofu turns a slight golden color. If the balls start turning brown"
column68: "the oil’s too hot or you’re frying them for too long. If the balls look oily or wet after frying"

title: Fearless Sous Vide Poached Eggs
instructions:
[Clip (or stand) sous vide machine to a tall large pot. Fill pot with warm water. Turn on machine and heat water to 153°F. Not 155°F—not 150°F. 153°F.
Gently lower eggs into water. (We like to put each one in a spoon and lower it in just to make sure it doesn’t crack.) Cook 25 minutes.
Transfer eggs to an ice bath and let cool. Transfer to an airtight container and chill; they'll keep in the fridge for about a week.

title: Halloumi Puff Pastry Twists
instructions:
[Preheat the oven to 200°C (180°C fan)/400°F/gas 6.
Line two baking trays (cookie sheets) with baking parchment.
Unroll one of the pastry sheets onto a lightly floured surface. Scatter nearly half of the grated cheeses over it. Sprinkle with the chives and season with a little salt and pepper.
Fold the pastry in half to cover the cheesy filling and roll out to the original size. Cut into strips 1cm (1/2 inch) wide and brush lightly with beaten egg. Twist them three or four times. Repeat with the remaining sheet of pastry.
Arrange the pastry twists on the baking trays and sprinkle with the remaining cheese. Bake in the oven for about 12 minutes until puffed up and golden brown.
Leave to cool completely before eating. You can store them in an airtight container for 48 hours."]"

title: Hickory-Smoked Baby Back Ribs

column15: "preheat the grill to low then turn off one side of the grill to achieve indirect heat. Place a drip tray on the cooler side of the grate and half fill the pan with warm water or the beer of your choice.\nDrain 2 chunks of hickory"

column18: "with the bone sides facing toward the heat. Close the lid and close the top vent on a charcoal grill about halfway. This will maintain a temperature between 250 and 300°F (120 and 150°C). Cook the ribs for 2 hours.\nOnce the ribs are on"

Simmer for 20 to 30 minutes or until the sauce reaches a glaze consistency. Remove the saucepan from the heat and set aside to cool.\nThe first batch of charcoal should be cooling down after 2 hours. Now is the time to use your chimney starter and get another batch of charcoal lit. Add the remaining wood chunks to the coals to get a little more smoke. If using a gas grill"
